_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Arkema has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) Update for the Torrance Distribution Terminal in accordance with Section 2745.10 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In accordance with paragraph (a) of this section, the update has been prepared within 5 years of the date of the original submittal.  (The plan was last submitted to the Torrance Fire Department [the Administering Agency] in June 2004).
The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP Update, in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP guidance for updates:
* The Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility was revised by Arkema using a proprietary technique.  
* The Offsite Consequence Analysis was revised using a current version of RMP*CompA?.  The affected population and list of sensitive receptors was revised using current population data and other resources.  
* The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems, and implementation of recommendations made in the last seismic review.  
* A three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, in accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations.  
* A revised RMP*SubmitA? has been prepared to reflect the changes in the RMP program since the 2004 update.  These revisions include the activities noted above in addition to routine updates of the various written compliance plans and programs.  
This Executive Summary discusses the current status of each of the RMP program elements.

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY
Arkema has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  Arkema is committed to operating and maintaining the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  Arkema has implemented a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of its

employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  These programs include both Arkema Chemical's Responsible CareA? requirements and governmental requirements, such as the EPA's RMP program and the CalARP RMP program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material, and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to employees, the public, and the environment.  Arkema management is committed to providing appropriate training to employees and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.
DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The facility is located at 19500 Mariner Avenue in the City of Torrance, California.  The facility is known as the Torrance Distribution Terminal (Terminal).  The activities conducted at the facility include the bulk storage, transfer, and blending of chemicals.  The Torrance terminal is recognized as a covered source under the RMP rule as the facility maintains quantities of a regulated substance above the threshold quantities listed in the RMP rule.  Currently, the only regulated substance present on-site in quantities above the threshold limit is vinyl acetate monomer (VAM).
Annual VAM throughput is approximately 43 million pounds.  VAM is received by tank rail cars and stored in one aboveground tank, Tank 26, dedicated for storage of VAM.  The facility is equipped to receive bulk VAM delivery by tank truck, but this method of receipt has not occurred in the past 5 years. The delivery truck method of receipt is an option in the event the facility can not receive VAM by rail. Tank 26 is described as follows:
* Internal floating roof tank with double deck pontoon rim seals;
* 265,000-gallon maximum capacity and 186,000-gallon operating capacity (using administrative controls);
* Secondary containment with a capacity of over 350,000 gallons; and
* Floating gauge for measuring liquid level.
VAM is transferred from Tank 26 to the adjac

ent UCARA? Emulsion Systems (UES) latex manufacturing plant through a pipeline, as needed. The facility is equipped to distribute bulk shipments of VAM to customers by tank truck, but this method of distribution has not occurred in the past 5 years and there are no plans to utilize this method of distribution.  
A network of product transfer piping is routed between the VAM storage, the truck loading station, and the adjacent UES latex plant.  All piping is coated to prevent corrosion and is supported by steel framework, or is securely fastened to concrete or asphalt platforms or foundations.  Underground sections of piping (two road crossings) are encased by an outer pipe to prevent corrosion and seismic damage.
HAZARD ASSESSMENT
RMP regulations require that each facility identify worst-case and alternative case release scenarios.  EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel that contains a regulated substance in a 10-minute period.  EPA defines alternative release scenarios as scenarios that are more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, and that reaches an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.  One or more alternative release scenarios are evaluated to define the distance to the specified endpoint.  Unless otherwise specified, no credit was taken for administrative controls or active mitigation measures in evaluating the off-site impact of the scenarios.
The zones of potential impact for the worst-case and alternative release were predicted using RMP*CompA? (Version 1.07) released by the EPA.  RMP*CompA? is an electronic tool to make the same calculations as performed manually by following the procedures described in EPAA?s guidance document, RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April, 1999).  
Worst-Case Release Scenario
The RMP regulation requires consideration of the catastrophic failure of the largest storage vessel on the facility as the worst-case release scenario.  There are two

large storage vessels for VAM on the facility: the 186,000 gallon VAM storage tank and the 30,000 railcar delivering VAM.  Both vessels were evaluated for the worst-case release scenario.  For VAM, at ambient temperature, the emission rate (and hence impact zone) will be proportional to the exposed liquid surface resulting from the vessel catastrophic failure, and not the tank volume.  There is no containment around a railcar on the siding and thus any release from the railcar would be uncontained.  The VAM storage tank has secondary containment that will limit the size of any VAM spill from the tank to less than that produced by an uncontained rail car spill.  Consequently the emission rate resulting from a catastrophic railcar failure will produce the worst-case off-site impact and was chosen as the worst-case release event.
The worst-case release scenario involves derailment of a railcar and subsequent release of the entire railcar contents.  A passive mitigation measure in place is coarse gravel along the rail spur.  The surface area of the resultant pool was estimated assuming a pool depth of 3 inches to reflect the reduction in horizontal extent of the pooled VAM due to percolation into the gravel.  The worst-case meteorological conditions defined by EPA for the worst-case release are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of F (very stable).  The liquid is assumed to be at a temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit (A?F).  The distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is approximately 1.9 miles (3,100 meters).  Approximately 91,600 persons reside within the 1.9-mile worst-case impact radius.
The catastrophic failure of a railcar while on a siding is a very low probability event.  Over the ten year period 1991-2000, there were on average only 72 serious incidents per year in the United States in which hazardous material was released from a railcar during an incident or accident (U.S. DOT, Hazardous Materials Safety, Hazardous

Materials Information System, 1/23/02).  Most of these incidents involved derailments and other energetic events that have high potential for causing a release of hazardous material.  A slowly moving or static railcar on a siding is rarely exposed to the energetic forces required to produce a catastrophic breach of the rail car tank. Loading accidents such as a hose breakage or disconnect can occur but these events would produce a lower release rate than the assumed catastrophic failure of the entire rail car. 
The more likely alternative-case release scenario consists of a valve leak in the piping leading to Tank 26 caused by an event such as a liquid hammer that damages the valve or a maintenance accident.  The release rate is 250 gallons per minute (gpm) based on the pump capacity and is assumed to continue for 10 minutes prior to shutoff.  The release is contained within the tankA?s concrete containment area.  The calculated endpoint distance for the alternative-case scenario is based on typical meteorological conditions (3 m/s wind speed and D atmospheric stability).  No active mitigation measures are assumed and dispersion is based on an urban environment.  The distance to the endpoint concentration of 0.26 mg/l is approximately 0.4 miles (600 meters).  Approximately 900 persons reside within the 0.4-mile alternative-case release impact radius.
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Terminal in Torrance, California.  Arkema's general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA and CalARP regulations as well as implementation of Arkema's Loss Prevention Principles and Episodic Risk Management System.  The TerminalA?s general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the following rules:
* California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program
* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Relea

se Prevention (RMP rule)
* 40 CFR Part 112, Oil Pollution Prevention (Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure)
* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan
* 40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)
The following is a brief outline of the general accident prevention program in place at the Torrance Distribution Terminal.
Compliance Audits
In accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations, a three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, AECOM, using a modified EPA RMP audit protocol.  No deficiencies were noted during the audit.
In addition, to help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Arkema periodically conducts corporate and plant-led audits to ensure the process operations comply with governmental and Arkema requirements.
Contractor Safety Program
Arkema uses contractors to supplement itsA? work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. During procurement of contractor services, the purchasing procedures require the verification of training and if applicable, certifications and licenses. Prior to initiating work at the facility, contractors are required to attend a safety briefing, which is documented and retained. Some contractors are required to work on or near process equipment; therefore, the facility has established procedures to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that are found during their work. At least one Arkema employee is assigned to each contractor. The Arkema employee is responsible for checking the work of each contractor to ensure Arkema procedures are followed. 
Employee Participation
Arkema encourages employees

to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Arkema engages its employees through formal and informal means. The management of change process is an intranet-based workflow process that requires each affected employee (i.e., Acknowledger) to review and acknowledge acceptance of the change or changes. The Acknowledger has the opportunity to raise concerns prior to finalizing changes at the facility.  At the beginning of each shift, a Shift Concerns Meeting is conducted to discuss issues and concerns covering all aspects of the employeeA?s work. Employees have access either through Arkema's intranet site or on-site library to information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Employees are encouraged to participate in the accident prevention program. The plan is documented and maintained on Arkema's Intranet site and on-site library. In addition, employees are involved in other aspects of the operation including, but not limited to, periodic inspections, operating procedure creation and incident investigations. 
Episodic Risk Management System
Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards that could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques. 
Equipment Design
Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to Arkema Chemical Engineering Standards, recognized industry standards, and/or governmental requirements. 
Incident Investigation
Arkema promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident by reviewing facts and developing corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The pro

duction leader is responsible for incident investigations at the facility.  Each shift has an immediate response coordinator responsible for implementing the RMP, including incident investigation.  No incidents occurred in the past 5 years requiring an incident investigation.
Management of Change
Arkema has a robust system to ensure that modifications to facilities and processes are reviewed by the appropriate technical staff, management, and affected employees (i.e., Acknowledgers). This is an electronic workflow process located on Arkema's Intranet site. The management of change requests are controlled and tracked to completion. This process requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before implementation. Specifically, the change is only initiated after each employee (reviewer or Acknowledger) has acknowledged his/her review and approval on the proposed change. At this point, the facility is authorized to move forward with implementation of the change.
Mechanical Integrity
Arkema has well-established practices and procedures to maintain tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, transfer hoses, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) developing written procedures, (2) conducting training, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  A preventative maintenance system (GEMTS) is used to track work orders, calibration schedules, testing and certification schedules, and completion of all the above. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the facilityA?s process equipment. 
Operating Procedures
Arkema maintains written procedures that provide detail on how to safely operate a process, including variou

s modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are maintained up-to-date by revising them as necessary. 
Operational Safety Program
Arkema has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed within this accidental release prevention program are implemented at every Arkema location.  This Program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements. 
Loss Prevention Principles
Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in Loss Prevention Principles (LPP). 
Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
Arkema conducts reviews just prior to startup to ensure that new and modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 
Process Hazard Analysis
Arkema conducted an internal audit of the Terminal on March 24 and 25, 2009.  A PHA was conducted during the audit using Arkema's proprietary A?Reactive Chemical Process Hazard AnalysisA? (RCPHA).  The principal staff performing the RCPHA was Marco Barrueta (Production Leader), Erwin Morfe (Run Plant Engineer), Ronald Weber (Plant EHS/Training), and Yin Ko (Plant Improvement/Projects).  This RCPHA audit is an update to the PHA/Hazard Operability Study (HazOp) performed for the original Risk Management Prevention Program (RMPP) plan and the RMP.  
The RCPHA methodology consists of a checklist designed by Arkema for use in internal reactive chemical and PHA audits.

Table 1 lists the major topic addressed in the RCPHA questionnaire.  For each question in the questionnaire, there are columns for a yes/no/not applicable response, a response column, columns to check the work discipline affected, and an action item column.  In addition to the RCPHA questionnaire, there is a second questionnaire that is used for field validation to be used in conjunction with the RCPHA.
There have been no significant changes to the VAM process at the Terminal since the preparation of the previous RMP and PHA.  While truck loading of VAM is not occurring, the facility retained the equipment and the capability to distribute VAM via tank truck.  Currently, all VAM at the terminal is received by railcar and is delivered by pipeline to the adjoining Arkema facility. 
As part of the RMP Update, the RCPHA developed during the March 2009 audit was reviewed by AECOM for completeness and applicability. There were no significant findings identified during the RCPHA or during AECOMA?s review of the RCPHA.  All RCPHA audit action items were entered into an Arkema's Event and Action Tool (i.e., database) and each item was assigned for follow-up.
External Events Analysis
AECOM reviewed the seismic assessment portion of the Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) seismic assessment conducted in December 1995 and updated in October 1999 for the Union Carbide Torrance Distribution Terminal and ENSRA?s Review of CalARP  Seismic Assessment and Walkthrough Findings for Arkema Torrance Distribution Terminal Facility conducted in December 2003.  After the review, AECOM conducted a walkthrough at the Terminal to confirm whether recommended modifications had been completed.
The 1995 RMPP seismic assessment and 1999 update of the Terminal included the following areas: rail car offloading area, tanker truck loading area, VAM storage tank, and associated piping and pumps.  The supplemental seismic review performed in 2003 evaluated the Terminal and aforementioned areas.

Based on a review of the recommendations provided in the 1995 and 1999 seismic assessments, the 2003 seismic update, and a walkthrough of the facility, it appears that the recommended modifications have been adequately implemented.  No additional areas of concern were identified during AECOM's walkthrough.
In addition, the PHA is supplemented with an external events analysis that addresses additional possible mechanisms for system failure.  No recommendations are made as a result of the analysis.  
Process Safety Information 
Arkema keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date and available to operating personnel. 
Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure and level control) in the LPP documents.  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, automated operating systems, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 
The facility maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a means for establishing inspection and maintenance activities. 
Safe Work Practices 
Arkema has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for

safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 
Training/Certification Programs 
To complement the written procedures for process operations, Arkema has implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for all employees involved in operating a process.  After employees demonstrate having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration), they are certified to work independently.  In addition, trained technical staff is available 24 hours a day to support operations. 
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving a CalARP RMP chemical at the Torrance Distribution Terminal that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation, shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage. 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 
The Torrance Distribution Terminal maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 
* Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 
* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, 
* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public,
* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements (if a releas

e occurs), and 
* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 
The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. 
The overall emergency response program for Arkema in Torrance is coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Arkema conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the emergency response organizations.  In addition, Arkema Chemical's Hazardous Emergency Leaks Prevention (HELP) team located in Torrance responds to accidental releases from transportation incidents occurring in the continental U.S. 
The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department. 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Torrance Distribution Terminal completes a thorough review of the affected VAM system(s) each time a design change is implemented and reviews the standard operating procedures every three years.  Arkema's audit team revalidates the PHA every five years from the date of the initial PHA.  Arkema is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.  These on-going programs aim to improve process safety.
Based on the compliance audit, review of the OCA, PHA, and seismic assessment, no changes to the management or equipment is recommended at this time.
